Political Superintendent's Office, Jacobahad, Ibth August 1870. A day or two ago in Durbar, when discussing a matter affecting tlte Chief of the Bdog- tee tribe, in which the latter,* according to the custom ^Through his son ShalilwzKhau. 0 f a cen tury, deprecated the Khan's interference with the internal economy and management of his tribe, and solicited permission to address a petition to His Highness on the subject, the Khelat Vakeel remarked that there was no doubt about the Khan's being ' Khan of Beloochistan,' there by implying, as I understood him, that the Khan ought to interfere in the tribal arrange ments of the Murree and Boogtee Chiefs. 2. I refrained from taking notice of the remark, a number of Belooch being present ; but the use of this unusual title, in connection with the matter under discussion, at once called to my mind Captain Harrison's recent introduction of it, as reported in para. 10 ot my letter No. 1127, dated 4th instant, and as the Vakeel would not have adopted the expres sion, except under instructions from Khelat, his doing so, has confirmed the opinion given in para. 23 of my letter No. 1125, dated 30th ultimo ; as also those regarding the incipient- intrigue with the Seistan Belooch, referred to in my letters Nos. 1120 and 1127 of the 4th instant. I therefore addressed the accompanying letter No, 1151, dated 13th instant, to Captain Harrison, which I beg to forward ior your information, in continuation of tin correspondence quoted above. 3. titleInfo.title: Letter No.1154 of 1870 from Colonel Robert Phayre, Political Superintendent, Frontier Upper Sind, Jacobabad to Colonel William Lockyer Merewether, The Commissioner in Sind, Kurrachee [Karāchi]

mods.abstract: Letter regarding a Durbar at which matters affecting the Chief of the Boogtee tribe were being discussed and reporting that during the discussion the Khan of Khelat [Kalāt]'s Vakeel referred to him as the Khan of Beloochistan [Baluchistan] and that he therefore had the right to interfere in the internal economy and management of the Boogtee tribe.Colonel Phayre goes on to discuss the unusual title of Khan of Beloochistan, which had previously been used in correspondence from Captain Harrison, Political Agent at Khelat, and his belief that the Vakeel would only use such a title on instruction from the Khan and expressing his concerns that the Khan may use the title of claim sovereignty over the Seistan [Sīstān] Belooch [Baluch] as well as stating that as Khelat is a British protectorate it may be believed that the British Government approved of the use of the title.Enclosed with the letter is No.1151 of 1870 from Colonel Phayre to Captain Charles Henry Harrison, Political Agent at Khelat, 13 August 1870, and asking the Captain to report where the term 'Khan of Beloochistan' had originated and reminding the Captain that the British Government's official title for the Khan was 'Khan of Khelat' and that he should use that title in all official correspondence.
